item.title: no-KYC only. Avoid the creep
item.description: This article by Bitcoin Q+A was published on bitcoinqna.github.io website. Contribute. What is KYC? # KYC or ‘Know your customer’ is a regulation that any businesses with a banking relationship has to abide by. Bitcoin exchanges are no different. These rules are imposed worldwide and are geared towards ensuring that a business acting as a money exchange and/or transmitter has ‘suitable’ information on every customer they serve. Within the Bitcoin space, ‘creeping KYC’ is a disease that is slowly spreading.

item.title: Bitcoin Privacy
item.description: While Bitcoin can support strong privacy, many ways of using it are usually not very private. With a proper understanding of the technology, bitcoin can indeed be used in a very private and anonymous way. This article was published on en.bitcoin.it wiki. Contribute. As of 2019 most casual enthusiasts of bitcoin believe it is perfectly traceable; this is completely false. Around 2011 most casual enthusiasts believed it is totally private; which is also false.

item.title: Bitcoin Becomes Critical
item.description: An EU draft resolution calling for a “balance” between encryption and surveillance once again underscored the need for technologies like Bitcoin. This article by Peter Chawaga was published on Bitcoin Magazine website. Contribute. On November 6, 2020, the Council of the European Union released a “Draft Council Resolution on Encryption.” The document is supposed to serve as a precursor to a final text to be presented to the Council, on November 19 for potential legal adoption.

item.title: CoinJoin Overview
item.description: This article by @BitcoinOnly_ and @6102bitcoin was published on 6102bitcoin.com website. Contribute. Background # Bitcoin transactions are public by nature; they map inputs (unspent utxo’s) to outputs (new unspent utxo’s) in a way that is auditable by anyone with access to the bitcoin blockchain (the history of transactions). Yet interpreting these transactions and the Blockchain is a non-trivial task, because Bitcoin transaction are not equivalent to Bitcoin payments. The Problem # Because anyone can see the links between transaction inputs and outputs it’s possible for anyone to analyse previous and future transaction behavior in an attempt to link multiple Bitcoin addresses to the same entity, this process is sometimes called clustering.

item.title: Bitcoin Fungibility
item.description: This presentation was introduced by TDevD on Dirtcoin Diaries podcast. Okay, so basically it’s just my views as to the current state of Bitcoin fungibility. I’ll try to avoid any stream of consciousness stuff and get right to the point. I’ll start off with playing a devil’s advocate. Perhaps, all of our problems with fungibility is our fault, maybe we dropped the ball and allowed Bitcoin to be defined as “money” by the state.
